Spiderman Lunges are a dynamic mobility exercise primarily targeting hip flexors, glutes, hamstrings, and inner thighs (adductors), while also engaging the core, lower back, and even chest/shoulders (especially with rotations) for stabilization, improving overall hip flexibility and range of motion from a high plank position with forward foot placement and deep hip movement. The movement pattern involves transitioning from a plank, stepping one foot outside the hand, and deepening the lunge, often adding torso rotations for a full-body stretch and core engagement. Muscles Worked 

• Primary Movers/Stretch Targets: Hip Flexors (Iliopsoas), Glutes (Maximus, Medius), Hamstrings, Adductors (inner thighs). 
• Stabilizers/Secondary: Core (Abdominals, Obliques), Lower Back, Chest, Shoulders, Triceps (especially with rotation variations). [1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8]  

Movement Pattern & Benefits 

• Start: High plank position, hands under shoulders, body in a straight line. 
• Action: Step one foot forward to the outside of the hand, lowering hips. 
• Deepening (Optional): Lower elbow/forearm towards the instep (same side as front foot) for a deeper stretch. 
• Rotation (Optional): Extend the same arm towards the ceiling, rotating the torso. 
• Return: Push off the front foot to return to the plank. 
• Key Benefit: Great for unlocking tight hips, improving hamstring/hip flexor flexibility, and core stabilization during movement. [2, 5, 6, 9, 10, 11]
